speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We will hear argument in No. 06-618, the Office of Senator Mark Dayton against Brad Hanson.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Do you think -- do you think that we owe any special measure of respect to the Congress, that is most intimately concerned with the Speech or Debate Clause, with their view that this is, this legislation is compatible with that clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But what we are involved with in this case is Congress subjecting itself to the laws that govern all other employers.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which is what the statute says, and so how could the statute possibly be unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, the Constitution - - I mean, the statute has within itself a Speech or Debate Clause exception. Now, I guess you can argue that a lower court might not accurately provide the Speech or Debate Clause protection that is due, but that, that doesn't meet, it seems to me, the, the jurisdictional requirement that, that the constitutionality of the statute be called into question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, that doesn't comply with Section 412, which says that an appeal may be taken directly to the Supreme Court from "any interlocutory or final judgment decree of order of court upon the constitutionality of any provision of the Act." Now, and as-applied challenge is not a challenge to the constitutionality of the provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Isn't there a further problem here, though, that the order of the district court gave no explanation? We have no way of knowing exactly why the court ruled the way it did, and for that reason the appeal, the review, was that the original appeal was taken properly to the court of appeals, so that we are here not on appellate jurisdiction, but cert jurisdiction, if at all.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, there'S no direct appeal. We have appellate jurisdiction only if there's a direct appeal and there's no direct appeal. This is coming from the court of appeals.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: What pages are the text of 412 set out on? You're going to have to help me here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, why wasn't the ruling of the district court a ruling upon the constitutionality of the statute as applied? As I understand it, you moved to dismiss the case on the ground that an individual performing the duties that Mr. Dayton performed cannot sue a member of Congress for employment discrimination and the district court denied that. Why isn't that a ruling on the constitutionality of the, of the statute as applied?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Was there a dispute about the nature of his duties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Not how you characterize his duties, but what his duties actually were. Was there a dispute about that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But didn't the district court rule that somebody performing those duties can constitutionally be tried -- bring suit, and it doesn't, and it doesn't violate the Speech or Debate Clause? So I don't see how that's not a ruling on the constitutionality of the statute as applied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Don't you agree with Justice Scalia -- Justice Alito? Don't you agree with Justice Alito? I thought he's saying it's a ruling on constitutionality.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: My problem is, it's extraordinary. We have very few direct appeal cases any more and I, I am loathe to read Section 412 as embracing a decision by a court that a particular use of this statute was unconstitutional. You say it was, the statute was unconstitutional as applied. That's sloppy language. It really means that this application of the statute or the use of the statute for this purpose was unconstitutional. I think that's something different from saying that it was an order of the court upon the constitutionality of any provision. Which provision of this Act has been held to be unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Which -- but it hasn't been held to be unconstitutional. It's perfectly constitutional. You're just saying it can't be used in this particular case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, read the language. It says "The constitutionality of any provision of this act," not "the constitutionality of the application of any provision of this act."

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What is that citation? I was looking for that. Is that cited in your brief?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Thank you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But in the flag case the whole statute was either valid or not. There weren't different applications, were there?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You mean we held that the statute was constitutional on its face?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'll look at Eichman, but it's not my recollection of the case, that the whole, the essence of the duty imposed by, under the statute was held.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but there's always an application or there's no case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Absent some declaratory judgment provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We simply didn't rule hold was a right to burn flags in some cases and not others.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What -- what had the lower court held? It isn't a question of what we held; it's a question of what the lower court had held. Had the lower court held that it was unconstitutional?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, but that can mean -- you can always dispose of a, of a facial challenge by just saying we don't have to reach the facial question; we can decide it on an as applied question. But in order to get here in the first place, it has to be a challenge to the constitutionality of a provision of the Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And in we recite that the district court held the Act unconstitutional as applied to appellees and dismissed the charges.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I realize, before you leave that I realize that on a jurisdictional issue like that we have an obligation to raise it ourselves. But I'm - - I'm -- I'm curious, was -- was jurisdiction contested in that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: MS. MANNING: Okay. In any case, this Court should accept the petition, take this case on a petition for writ because the decision of the court of appeals was upon a question of Federal law that is an important question. Moving to my Speech or Debate Clause argument, with respect to Speech or Debate Clause, this Court has held that all acts that are within the legitimate legislative sphere are protected by Speech or Debate Clause immunity. And the Court has defined what is inside that sphere as anything that is part of the due functioning of the legislative process. And when an employee is an alter ego, that is, a second self of a member, that employee by definition is actually performing part of the member's job. He is performing legislative acts so he is in this sphere. He is doing something that is part of the due functioning of the legislative process. He is in that sphere.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What does he do? I mean I looked at what he does in 74, 75, 76a. He seems to spend a lot of time moving furniture. He lists that twice. He runs the office. And he represents, he is out in the local office somewhere and he talks to constituents. I mean, he doesn't even appear in the Senate office except very rarely in which case he is doing casework. So I guess if he is included in that, I mean so is a full-time furniture mover.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I have the whole list here. What here suggests, he ever -- he doesn't even write a statement for the floor. There is nothing here that suggests one word of anything he did ever went to a committee meeting, to a floor of the Senate, anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What are the words?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I agree with that one. I just said he doesn't do anything that gets to the floor of the Senate, that gets to a committee report, that gets to a committee hearing. Now what in there -- and you said it was not contested, so I guess the best source if it's not contested is his affidavit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh. Where does it say that? He drafted legislation that was then introduced?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Where does it say that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, he didn't do exclusively that stuff anyway. We can certainly all agree on that. And why isn't it sufficient that when any of those issues are, his activities in any of those capacities are sought to be introduced into evidence, anyone tries to contradict them, then you can bring in your Speech or Debate Clause objection?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why is the whole suit precluded?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I'm puzzled. Firing somebody is a legislative act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Firing someone is a legislative act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That's part of -- how many second selves would there be? (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: On the Senator's staff?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: How many second selves? Of -- what universe are you covering? Who is not a second self, who works in a Senator's office?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Maybe he was the 23rd self. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I think you have to figure out when he was hired.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What's wrong with this? I found what you're talking about here. It says in paragraph 13, contrary to what he says in his own evaluation, that Senator Dayton's staff, including Mr. Hanson -- that's a little uncertain, what they mean by that -- introduced a bill and drafted it. Okay? And then on paragraph 14 they say on November 15th, 2001, Mr. Hanson -- just as you said -- planned a Senate Government Affairs Committee meeting, selected hearing witnesses and prepared questions. Now suppose that we did as the court, lower court wanted to do, say let's just see if that becomes relevant. Because it's possible, given his other tasks that those two incidents, one on November 15th and the other, whenever help he gave to the drafting, had nothing to do with his being fired and nobody claims that. So what they said is let's wait and see if that becomes relevant. Now what's wrong with that solution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Let's make an absurd case out of it which I'm trying to do a little bit to get you to focus on it. Let's suppose he got fired because he didn't move the furniture properly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Isn't that a -- can you give me examples of cases where that Act applies?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Can you give me instances in which employees of an the office of a Senator are covered by these obligations and cannot invoke the Speech or Debate Clause? What's the classic example where you can't invoke the Speech or Debate Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes. Because it seems to me that your argument just completely eviscerates the intent of the Congress in passing this Act.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, except the Act itself has a provision for office of Senators.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And so it seems to me you're giving no effect to that. You say there is a hole in the process the minute the furniture mover is gone?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If this statute - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Wouldn't they get into - - no, you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If this statute was set up so that the defendant here was the Senate, as opposed to the office of a Senator, would you still say that this suit couldn't go forward?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In what sense would the member be called to answer under those circumstances, if the member isn't a defendant and has no financial liability and is able to invoke the clause as an evidentiary privilege? In what sense would the Speech or Debate Clause be applicable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well why doesn't it matter who the defendant is? Because I don't, this so-called office of Senator Mark Dayton is a construct that I understand, and there is no immunity problem there. But if, if that office is gone now and getting to your hypothesis, if the, if -- if the true party is the Senate of the United States, has there been any unequivocal waiver of immunity with respect to the entire Senator or the Senate of the United States as an institution?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I'm Justice Souter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You're very flattering. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but I was just going to say if this case continues we've got to accept the proposition that the Office of Senator Mark Dayton is still a, some kind of an entity that has got to be accorded reality by the judiciary, right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And how do we do it? I mean, you've said -- I don't want to go too far with a metaphor, but you spoke a moment ago of there being sort of a, what did you say, a hole or a space in the legislative sphere when somebody is fired. In the sphere at the moment is totally empty. The Senator's gone. Everybody knows that this, this office of Senator Mark Dayton is a totally fictional construct. And in reality, as you point out, the money is going to come out of the Senate or some Senate fund. If we allow this to go forward, we've got to face the reality that it's the Senate which is the defendant and there hasn't been a waiver of immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but at this point that's silly. There's no Senator. There's no office in any sense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: There's never an office. I mean, I think the office is just a fictional construct anyway. So what you say now has nothing to do with whether, whether this current Senator has, has departed from the scene. Even if he were still on the scene, there still wouldn't be any such thing as that office. It's just a fiction, and it would always be a suit against Congress, and so you say none of these suits can ever be brought.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why isn't it a waiver of sovereign immunity when you set up a suit that envisions a suit which will be paid off by the Senate? Why isn't that a waiver of sovereign immunity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Is it unequivocal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I mean, when it's done on the basis of this fiction, is that what we should accept as an unequivocal waiver?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: A physical, a physical office, yes. I mean, they didn't work in the hallway. But their staff salary was not paid out of their, quote, "office." It was paid out of the Senate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Setting it is quite different from paying it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Right. The Senate puts a limit on how much money it will spend for a particular Senator. That's all that amounts to. It doesn't hand him the money. It's still the Senate's money, isn't it? And what the Senate says is each office will have so much of a call upon our fund and no more.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Salzman.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The other side's contention is that the firing is itself a legislative act and so when you challenge the firing you are challenging the legislative act. What do you say to that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What if his dissent -- or defense, rather, to the charge is that he was very inefficient in giving me help in legislative hearings and so forth, or words of that kind which might be arguably a legislative act, and that Speech or Debate Clause forbids inquiry into the quality of his performing those duties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But maybe the Senator might argue that this is all privileged: It's the reason I fired him, but I can't go into it because I don't want to invade my own privilege not to discuss matters that are covered by the immunity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What's the test for intruding? If it would chill his exercise of the function in future cases, or if it requires him to talk about legislative decisions, or what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What if it required him to say how he allocated his resources, that he allocate his resources 10 percent to foreign affairs issues, 50 percent to health care issues? Would that involve is - - is that a Speech or Debate Clause problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: That doesn't quite capture the problem that I'm having. It's not that the plaintiff can't inquire. Usually they can't. But my thought is that the defendant cannot put in his own defense without waiving the privilege that would otherwise be applicable. So he's sort of in a dilemma. Either I give up my constitutional right not to talk about this stuff or I've got to waive that right in order to give a full explanation of why I discharged the plaintiff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Or he just wrote a lousy memo. In order to demonstrate it's lousy, I've got to talk about legislative matters.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Even if the Senator did not have a defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes, but what if the Senator doesn't want to put it in? I mean, what if he does not want to waive the privilege? Is his only choice in effect to sit moot and lose the case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: "Mute" I guess I should have said.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, why don't, why doesn't that -- why doesn't being placed in that dilemma in effect implicate the clause, and why can't he invoke the clause as a basis for dismissal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, yes, so far as the member's immediate financial concern, they took care of it. But I'm not sure about the careful way. They in effect said, you know, if this gets into Speech or Debate Clause issues they prevail. And that kind of just leaves us with no solution for the problem that Justice Stevens raised and that I'm concerning with, unless there's, there's going to be an automatic dismissal when the member says, look, I cannot respond to this without getting into, into acts within the legislative process which are privileged. Unless you want to recognize that as kind of an absolute defense upon its invocation, I don't see how we get out of the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That would go for a stenographer in a committee hearing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, it could or couldn't be. I mean, I mean if the legislator, the Senator, says, I think relevant to my dismissal of this individual is the individual's performance that revealed itself in a speech or debate that I gave in the House, and if that's relevant, then why isn't that the end of the case, they can't bring it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, all he'd have to say is it's relevant to my decision to fire the person. Now, surely a jury or whoever -- it's probably a jury matter, I guess, on this -- is entitled to take that into account. If it's something the jury is entitled to take into account, you are questioning what that Senator did in the speech or debate and you are questioning it in another place, namely, a court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Have any cases gone through a district court on the merits under this Act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Have any cases under this Act gone to a district court to judgment on the merits?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I have one question. The Appellants here were the ones that appealed to the court of appeals? Did they appeal from the district court?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But under 1291, the United States Court of Appeals does not have jurisdiction where direct review may be had in the Supreme Court. So it seems to me that their position contradicts their own basis for jurisdiction here. Do you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but my point is that the Appellants are telling us that this is appealable here directly, but if that's so they shouldn't have gone to court of appeals, they shouldn't have gone to the court of appeals; they're untimely when they come here.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Salzman. Mr. Caballero.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: And there's no jurisdiction under 412 because?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Can we go back a step. I just -- you said this is appealable and your reason for it being appealable was because the statute itself - - you said it was not appealable and the reason not is because the statute itself said that this has to be applied consistent with the Speech or Debate Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's your reason. So I take it, what about the reason that's been given, that this is an as-applied challenge instead of on its face? What about that as a reason for it not being appealable?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: No, no, no, I'm not asking about the argument you are making. I want to ask about an argument you aren't making, that the reason -- I'll ask about the one you are making in a second. The reason I want to know about -- I want to know about the other possible reason for not being appealed, namely that this is as applied and not on its face. They don't strike down any provision. What's your view about that one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That is correct. And what you do about this case, what is it, Eichman?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In Eichman, I was able to get out the district court and the last part of the district court, the last line of the district court, it says the law under which these three -- let me begin again -- the law under which these three defendants have been prosecuted is unconstitutional, which seems to me to contradict what Appellant's counsel told us about what happened in the district court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It wouldn't matter anyway, because our prior decisions that do not explicitly refer to jurisdictional questions are not authority on jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: We have that firm rule: When we take a case and don't get into the jurisdictional question, it is not precedent for the fact -- -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So then a holding of a district court in your opinion, the holdings say, imaginary, is that no one who actually works in an office of a Senator and who ever worked on any matter having to do with legislation falls within this Act because that would violate the speech and debate clause. That would be quite major in its implication. But you're saying there is no appeal on that because it's as applied.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Does that mean if I go to your argument -- I mean, the problem with your argument it seems to me is that that leaves no room for this appellate provision at law, because the only reason that anything is likely to be unconstitutional in this area, at least 99 percent of it, would be Speech or Debate Clause violation. So in that interpretation of the statute there is no direct appeal, or hardly ever.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: We were told that 75 percent of the employees who were covered by the Act do not work for an individual member. So how could, how could a provision to be facially unconstitutional under the Speech or Debate Clause?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What could it possibly be? And if it couldn't possibly be then what did Congress have in mind when it provided it for an interlocutory appeal from a ruling on the constitutionality of the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. That, that may make sense. I, I wondered why -- why they would provide for an appeal on constitutionality if they had in mind the Speech or Debate Clause stuff, when the legislation itself says that nothing herein shall be deemed a violation of speech.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But it will -- the money is simply Senate money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But none of those funds are, as I understand it, are somehow subtracted from or contributed by the funds of individual senatorial offices while a Senator is in office. I am assuming that those, that there is a separate appropriation for the payment of -- of any such judgment, is that correct?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. In the real world then at this point isn't the Senate the -- the party?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Ms. Manning, you have about a minute left. REBUTTAL ARGUMENT BY JEAN M. MANNING, ON BEHALF OF APPELLANT

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Right. I have one -- one question. Could the Senate direct you to pay this judgment?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Direct your office to - - to do that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Because it -- suppose they thought there was liability and if you say yes, then I need to know why you and counsel who just addressed this are on different sides of the case, if you're both representing the Senate.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Could it, if it chose?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Ms. Manning - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Ms. Manning. The case is submitted.
